g.text: Apart fromthermal expansion of the unit cell and larger Atomic Displacement Parameters (ADPs),
the current structure is the same as the one originally determined. There was a single molecule of
in an asymmetric unit, with the pyrene moiety almost exactly planar (the average planes of the
terminal benzene rings are inclined at an angle of 3.3(3)
), and the carbonyl substituent rotated out of
the average pyrene plane by only 8.0(2)
] may be responsible for the almost perfect planarity of the molecule.
-stacks in [100] direction, where stacked moieties are related by
). The shortest distances between the average pyrene
planes within a stack are 3.464(4) Å (“grey” and “purple” molecules in Figure
). The angle at which the pyrene moiety is inclined with respect to
. Viewed from above (ca. along [100]), molecules in
signiﬁcant horizontal overlap of the pyrene fragments (Figure
). In particular, the molecules with a
slightly longer interplanar distance show signiﬁcant vertical overlap of pyrene fragments. A
can therefore be considered as a “stack of dimers”. Such stacking may enable the effective formation
or stabilization of a few imaginable excited multimers in the electronic excitation process.
Top: a fragment of the inﬁnite
crystallographic centers of symmetry indicated as yellow dots; the independent molecule of
the asymmetric unit represented in grey, the two closest neighbors of
purple and magenta, with symmetry codes of the molecules on the left; the centers of each pyrene
moiety represented as blue dots. Middle and bottom-views perpendicular to the average pyrene
planes, roughly along [100], illustrating the vertical overlap of pyrene moieties and the lateral shifts
of their centers; the longer interplanar distance (purple) is associated with larger vertical overlap of
